content.raw:
The use case is similar, but the API has 2 main differences from `glu`:

1. The implementation here is simpler, because you can't specify the up vector (it's always +Z)
1. Instead of an "eye position", here we give a "direction" (or as @scpeters suggested, an "observer offset"). I think there are use cases for both, if you know the eye's position and just want to rotate it to face the target, the `glu` approach is more convenient. Here, I basically copied a chunk of code which we're [repeatedly](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issues/1998/duplicate-angle-math-calculations) using in Gazebo. It looks like our main use case starts from not knowing the eye position, but I haven't looked at all the cases. It could be interesting to have both functions here, I can implement them if we agree on the API.

The Ogre API also assumes we know the position and just changes orientation to face a point.
